author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request does not meet the guidelines for auto-merging. Please make sure that you have read the [General registry README](https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/blob/master/README.md). The following guidelines were not met:

- Name is not at least five characters long
- Repo URL does not end with /name.jl.git, where name is the package name
- The following dependencies do not have a `[compat]` entry that is upper-bounded and only includes a finite number of breaking releases: CSV, DataFrames, ImageMagick, Images, LightXML, ProgressMeter, julia
- Package name similar to 8 existing packages.
  1. Similar to Tau. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  2. Similar to Yao. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  3. Similar to Tar. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  4. Similar to Jags. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  5. Similar to JLD. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  6. Similar to Why. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  7. Similar to JDF. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  8. Similar to Lazy. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.

Note that the guidelines are only required for the pull request to be merged automatically. However, it is **strongly recommended** to follow them, since otherwise the pull request needs to be manually reviewed and merged by a human.

After you have fixed the AutoMerge issues, simple retrigger Registrator, which will automatically update this pull request. You do not need to change the version number in your `Project.toml` file (unless of course the AutoMerge issue is that you skipped a version number, in which case you should change the version number).

If you do not want to fix the AutoMerge issues, please post a comment explaining why you would like this pull request to be manually merged.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have also read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

Hi Eric,

I have renamed the package to:

JayTracer

and resubmitted my registration on JuliaHub. I also added [compat] lines to
the Project.toml file. I hope I did that right. I found this explanation:

https://pkgdocs.julialang.org/v1/compatibility/

but that webpage does not explain how to come up with upper bound values.
Do you just have to indicate some future (i.e. not yet existent) version
number? So, if a dependency is at version 0.2.3 I would just use 0.3 as the
upper bound under [compat]?

Thanks,

Martin



Op ma 15 mrt. 2021 om 13:47 schreef Eric Hanson ***@***.***>:

> Reopened #31814 <https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/31814>.
>
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/31814#event-4458490656>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AEPAFBVXFQFTOQVVPZW3OODTDX6WNANCNFSM4ZCRKINQ>
> .
>

Great! I will close this one then in favor of the new one: https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/32270.

> I also added [compat] lines to
the Project.toml file. I hope I did that right. I found this explanation:
>
> https://pkgdocs.julialang.org/v1/compatibility/
>
> but that webpage does not explain how to come up with upper bound values.
Do you just have to indicate some future (i.e. not yet existent) version
number? So, if a dependency is at version 0.2.3 I would just use 0.3 as the
upper bound under [compat]?

If you just put `name_of_dependency = "0.2.3."`, that actually means "any version [semver](https://semver.org/) compatible with 0.2.3" which means any version on or after 0.2.3 but strictly before 0.3. So the upper bounds are actually implicit already when you use that syntax.
